verses.text: On that day, a fountain will be opened for the house of David and for those who live in Jerusalem, to cleanse them from sin and impurity.
verses.comment: This verse foretells a future day of cleansing for God's people, which Christians see spiritually fulfilled in Christ's sacrifice (John 19:34). The 'fountain' symbolism recalls the water and blood flowing from Jesus' side, pointing toward the sacramental mysteries that bring forgiveness and purity to believers.

verses.text: And on that day, declares the LORD of Hosts, I will erase the names of the idols from the land, so they will never be remembered again. I will also remove the prophets and the spirit of impurity from the land.
verses.comment: This verse stresses God's intention to purge idolatry and false prophecy, purifying worship. The erasure of idols and false spirits echoes the New Testament call to single-hearted faith in Christ and acceptance of authentic teaching, guided by apostolic tradition.

verses.text: If anyone still prophesies, his father and mother who bore him will say to him, 'You must not live, because you speak lies in the name of the LORD.' And his own parents will pierce him through when he prophesies.
verses.comment: The measure taken against false prophets reflects Deuteronomy's strict warnings, upholding truth even over familial bonds. The concern for doctrinal purity is seen here, connecting to the Christian responsibility to safeguard accurate teaching.

verses.text: On that day, every prophet will be ashamed of their vision when they prophesy, and they will no longer wear a hairy cloak to deceive.
verses.comment: The prophet's hairy cloak was a traditional sign of prophetic authority (2 Kgs. 1:8), but here it is abandoned, illustrating the end of deception. This points ahead to authentic shepherds recognized not by outward signs, but by truth and apostolic succession.

verses.text: He will say, 'I am not a prophet; I am a farmer, for the land has been my livelihood since youth.'
verses.comment: The denial of prophetic status emphasizes humility and turning away from false claims. This humility aligns with Amos's similar denial (Amos 7:14), encouraging discernment between genuine and false ministry within the community.

verses.text: And if someone asks, 'What are these wounds on your chest?' he will answer, 'I received them at the house of my friends.'
verses.comment: This mysterious verse foreshadows wounds inflicted by friends, interpreted by many Christian fathers as a prophecy of Christ's suffering among his own people (see Ps. 22; John 20:27). The theme of redemptive suffering ties to the idea of sacrificial love and the visible marks of commitment to God's people.

verses.text: 'Awake, sword, against my shepherd, against the man who is close to me,' declares the LORD of Hosts. 'Strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered; I will turn my hand against the little ones.'
verses.comment: Directly quoted by Jesus as fulfilled in his arrest and crucifixion (Matt. 26:31), this verse reveals the mystery of the shepherd — one especially close to the LORD — being struck and the flock scattered. Strong christological implications, linking priestly and sacrificial themes carried forward into the community that emerges from Christ's Passion.

verses.text: In all the land, declares the LORD, two-thirds will be cut off and perish, but one-third will be left in it.
verses.comment: This solemn warning reflects the division of judgment and salvation; the preserved remnant theme appears often in prophecy (Isa. 6:13). Christian interpretation often sees here the faithful remnant, preserved through trial, closely connected to the idea of the 'little flock' gathered and sustained by God's grace.

verses.text: I will bring the one-third through the fire, refine them as silver is refined, and test them as gold is tested. They will call on my name, and I will answer them. I will say, 'They are my people,' and they will say, 'The LORD is my God.'
verses.comment: God's loving discipline purifies his people, echoing New Testament themes of perseverance through trial (1 Pet. 1:7). The mutual recognition between God and his people hints at the covenantal language, fulfilled spiritually in the Church, where intimacy with the Lord is experienced through sacramental life and continual fidelity.
